Some may think "well just increase the size of the chip", but that actually doesn't work, increasing the size and amount of transistors doesn't increase the speed. An analogy would be to think of a large city that is too crowded. If it takes a person an hour to commute to work due to traffic then someone waved a magic wand and doubled the size of the city, there wouldn't be as much traffic, but the length of the commute increased just as much as the traffic decreased, so in the end the commute still takes an hour. In the same way, just increasing the size of a chip doesn't increase the speed, it's not the size that matters but the density of transistors, the maximum amount packed into a specified area.

P – type is when boron is injected into the silicon. Boron is missing an electron which creates a hole. These holes still conduct electricity as they move around.



N – type and P – type are neutrally charged. In N – type, it’s negative electrons that can move while in P – type it’s the positive hole that move.

A transistor is made with both N – type and P – type. Transistors are mainly made up of P – type conductors with some N – type conductors on the top right and left.


The left N – type conductor is called the Source, and the right is called the Drain. Both the N – type conductors have an electrical source. The P – type conductor also has an electrical source all the Gate that is separated from the P – type conductor by a layer of Oxide.

Depletion Layer is the area around where the N – type and P – type touch. In this area the extra electrons from the N – type move over to the P – type and fill the missing electrons. The depletion layer acts a barrier preventing electrons in the N – type area into the P – type.

The state that I’ve just described is when the transistor is off. To turn on the transistor, a small voltage is brought to the gate. This electricity attracts the electrons so much that the electrons overcome the depletion layer. From here the electrons move through the P – type conductor, through the other N – type conductor, and then through the drain.

This essentially creates a switch. With the transistor is off, power from the source is trapped in the left N – type conductor. But when the P – type conductor receives power, it creates a path for the electrons to the drain.

You are only explaining Mos-Fet type transtors, enhancement-MosFet's to be exact.

But i think they are easier to understand than BipolarJunctionTransistors where current affects current.

I would have started with the diode, talked about the 1.7V created be recombination, and that the depletion region accts a bit like a capacity since you can fill it up by applying reverse bias.

The next step would have been FieldEffectTransistors, for example a P-type wire with an N-Type ring around it.
And although there are only 2 pieces of semiconductor, jet 3 "poles", since the depletion-Layer affects the cross-section of wire that can conduct, applying voltage accross these 2 pieces will affect the resistance of the wire from completly open to completly "pinched-off"

After that would come the MosFet, where the depletionLayers shape is controled by the charges at the two plates of the capacitor formed by the Gate and the base, making it a 4-pole device, and that at first a depletionLayer is formed under the whole surface of the gate, until the creation of an InversionLayer(where N-Type will have holes and P-Type exess electrons), which will be the zone that conducts. In an enhancement-type MosFet that is.
In the case of an "depletion-type" MosFet, source and drain are connected by a thin layer (P or N- type) just nelow the gate and are thus in the "closed" state until voltage is applied to the gate. Here, the depletionLayer pinches off the conductive zone like in the FET described previously.

You could then add that the voltage from source to drain will cause the depletion and inversionLayer to deforme further, creating problems and increasing the Gate-base voltage necessary to change its state from insulating to conducting or vice versa.

I think only depletion-type MosFets are used today because they are simpler to "print", but this inherently limits CMOS-technology to NOT, NOR and NAND gates.
All other gates would have to be constructed by combining these 3 gates.
Likewise enhancement-type only CMOS would yield only Buffers, OR and AND Gates.

After that, it becomes fairly simple to create a "working" computer. Wether it is fast, power efficient or userfriendly is a whole other ball-game though.

Folks let's not get too hung up on this whole thing about "holes".  I've taken a half dozen courses on semiconductor physics, mostly at the graduate level.  This will annoy some of you, but please listen.  Holes are more than a mere space where an electron used to be.  An electron vacating its orbital position sometimes leaves a hole behind but not always.  In intrinsic silicon (undoped), electrons which leave their parent atom leave behind a hole.  This is because silicon has 4 electrons in its outer shell and silicon atoms bond in a crystal lattice structure of 4 atoms in a tetrahedron.  Since there are 4 electrons per atom, and 4 atoms, whenever an electron leaves its atom a hole exists.  But not the case with a donor atom, which is a group 5 atom on the periodic chart.  Take arsenic, it has 5 electrons in its outer shell.  When a silicon crystal is doped with As, there are still 4 atoms per tetrahedral bond.  But As has 5 electrons, the other 3 Si atoms have 4 in the outer shell.  If 1 electron leaves the As atom, there is NO HOLE LEFT BEHIND.  This is because all 4 energy states are filled by the 4 remaining electrons.  This is very important.  The loose electron is an excess carrier and as a result n type material, aka donor atoms, can easily conduct electrons.  They have high mobility since they are abundant and will not recombine with a hole as often as they would in intrinsic material or p type material.  Likewise a boron atom, an acceptor, is from the group 3 of periodic chart.  It has but 3 electrons in outer shell and without picking up or shedding electrons, there is a hole present since tetrahedral bonds consist of 4 shared electrons.  With only 3 a hole exists and free electrons statistically combine with said hole more readily than in intrinsic or donor material.  Bottom line - holes are more than just the absence of an electron, they are present when the number of electrons in the outer shell is less than the number of covalent bonds, which is 4 for Si.  A hole has an effective mass, charge, and bandgap energy.  A mere void does not.  When doping Si, some atoms get trapped in between atoms not forming a flawless crystal, known as interstitial atoms.  Electrons which leave these atoms DO NOT LEAVE A HOLE BEHIND.  Please understand not all holes are voids that used to have an electron.  Not all electrons leaving an atom generate a hole.  Have I helped?  Claude

You give the false, or incomplete impression that all that transistors can do is switch on and off. That is true of some mosfets, igbts, and scrs, however there are other types of mosfets and bjts that operate linearly. That is they are only partly off-depending upon a particular bias point and input signal. As the small input signal varies the transistor provides more or less conduction and usually more or less power. This action also results in a power gain, or signal gain. This action is also similar to a variable resistor. Instead of rapidly varying your big switch on and off, you could represent these transistors by slowly varying a potentiometer high and then low.  This is actually the idea behind the name "transistor" which is short for "transfer resistor". These types of transistors have low transconductance gain to prevent from switching rapidly and are used in audio or RF recievers and audio or RF  transmitter amplifiers.
